title: real analysis - Have you seen this PDE before?
body: Consider the second-order nonlinear PDE $$(\partial_x\partial_y\varphi)\cdot\varphi = \partial_x\varphi\,\partial_y\varphi.$$ This PDE is solved by all ('separable') functions $\varphi\in C^2(\Omega)$ of the form $\varphi(x,y) = \ell(x)\cdot r(y)$ (any $\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{R}^2$ open). I'd like to know whether each (classical) solution of the PDE is of this form. Are you aware of any 'uniqueness' results for the above PDE which might (dis)prove this? real-analysis ap.analysis-of-pdes mp.mathematical-physics calculus-of-variations Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 15, 2020 at 17:01 Overflowian 2,582 1 1 gold badge 13 13 silver badges 27 27 bronze badges asked Jul 15, 2020 at 9:53 fsp-b 453 2 2 silver badges 8 8 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 4 11 $\begingroup$ This equation is equivalent to $\partial_x \partial_y \log(\varphi) = 0$. This is the 2-dimensional wave equation for $\log(\varphi)$ in "null" coordinates. $\endgroup$ Igor Khavkine –  Igor Khavkine 2020-07-15 09:57:17 +00:00 Commented Jul 15, 2020 at 9:57 $\begingroup$ That settles it, thanks. @IgorKhavkine $\endgroup$ fsp-b –  fsp-b 2020-07-15 10:19:02 +00:00 Commented Jul 15, 2020 at 10:19 5 $\begingroup$ @fsp-b Not completely: it shows that it is true for positive solutions, but since the equation has compactly supported solutions, you can combine them to form solutions that aren't (globally) separable. $\endgroup$ Martin Hairer –  Martin Hairer 2020-07-15 10:27:30 +00:00 Commented Jul 15, 2020 at 10:27 1 $\begingroup$ Many thanks for your comment, @MartinHairer I in fact happen to be interested in positive solutions only, so for me, this in fact gives what I needed. $\endgroup$ fsp-b –  fsp-b 2020-07-15 10:35:27 +00:00 Commented Jul 15, 2020 at 10:35 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
